CONJUGATES: flavours (n. plural) | flavours (v. 3rd singular present) | flavouring (v. present participle, n.) | flavoured (v. past tense/past participle, adj.)
ETYMOLOGY: Middle English, from Old French flavour (smell, odor), from Latin flāre (to blow, breathe), related to flatus (a blowing). This is the British English spelling; American English uses 'flavor'.

MEANINGS.PATTERN:
[sth] has a flavour
the flavour of [sth]
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The distinctive aromatic quality or combination of taste and smell perceived in food or drink.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 食物或饮料特有的风味、味道或香气。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The subtle flavour of cinnamon balanced the tartness of the apples.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 肉桂的微妙风味平衡了苹果的酸涩。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A distinctive quality, characteristic, or feeling associated with a particular thing or place; an atmosphere or tone.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 特有的风格、特色、气氛或感觉。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The interior design has a distinctly Mediterranean flavour.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 室内设计具有明显的、地中海风格的特色。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To add a substance to food or drink to give it a particular flavour; to season.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 给食物或饮料调味，使其具有某种风味。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She decided to flavour the cake mixture with almond extract.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她决定用杏仁提取物给蛋糕混合物调味。
